importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the cargo plane crash in Hong Kong, marking a significant aviation safety incident and triggering investigations and public concern about airport safety protocols.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The exact time of the incident when the Emirates flight landed and veered off the runway, establishing a critical timeline for the crash and emergency response.

keyTakeAways: A cargo plane operated by Act Airlines under a wet lease agreement with Emirates skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport during landing at 03:50 local time.

The aircraft, a Boeing 747-481, collided with a patrol vehicle of airport security staff, killing two of them â€” a 30-year-old and a 41-year-old with seven and twelve years of experience respectively.
Both ground staff were found deceased, with the younger one confirmed dead at the scene and the older one later in hospital, and their bodies recovered from seven meters underwater.
All four crew members on the aircraft survived, having opened emergency doors and been rescued by fire services within two minutes of the crash.
The plane broke in half and was partially submerged, with visible cracks and a successful deployment of at least one emergency evacuation slide.
The Hong Kong Air Accident Investigation Authority (AAIA) is still searching for the flight data recorder and cockpit voice recorder (black boxes).
Criminal investigations are not ruled out due to the unusual nature of the incident and the absence of a distress signal.
The runway incident occurred on the north runway; the other two runways remain open, though at least 11 scheduled cargo flights were cancelled.
This is the second deadly incident at Hong Kong International Airport since its relocation to Chek Lap Kok in 1998, following a 1999 typhoon-related crash.
Airport officials confirm the patrol vehicle was outside the runway fencing at a safe distance, and state the plane did not send a distress signal.
The investigation will examine weather, runway conditions, aircraft status, crew actions, and landing path.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A cargo plane operated by Act Airlines under a wet lease agreement with Emirates, flight EK9788, skidded off the north runway at Hong Kong International Airport during landing at 03:50 local time, crashing through perimeter fencing and colliding with a patrol vehicle operated by Hong Kong airport security staff. Two ground staff, aged 30 and 41, died as a result; the Boeing 747-481 sustained significant damage and broke in half, though all four crew members survived due to a rapid emergency response. The Hong Kong Air Accident Investigation Authority is searching for the flight data and cockpit voice recorders. Officials confirm the patrol vehicle was safely outside the runway and that the aircraft did not send a distress signal. The incident marks the second deadly aviation event at the airport since its 1998 relocation, with the previous one in 1999 involving a China Airlines flight. At least 11 cargo flights were cancelled, and the affected runway remains closed.
title: Hong Kong cargo plane crash: Two dead after Emirates jet skids off runway into sea
